The legendary handling and quickness of the Model 70 Featherweight is justly famous among hunters everywhere.
 The Model 70 action offers Pre-’64 style Controlled Round Feeding, a Three-Position Safety and is highlighted by
 a jeweled bolt body with knurled bolt handle. Inside is the M.O.A. Trigger System, the finest trigger ever offered 
in a bolt-action with zero take up, zero creep and zero overtravel. Like the original Featherweight, the angled 
comb Grade I walnut stock still features the Schnabel fore-end and satin finish with elegant cut checkering.
 A premium Pachmayr® Decelerator® pad helps soak up felt recoil. It’s available in the most popular long 
and short action calibers, including WSM chamberings.
Generations of serious hunters have made the Model 70 Featherweight the iconic all-around rifle for any hunt. 
Easy-to-carry, accurate and utterly reliable, the Featherweight is ideal for deer, varmints, hogs and antelope. 

ProStaff 3-9x40 Matte BDC 
Patented BDC reticle: The BDC reticle allows hunters to hold “dead-on” at ranges exceeding 
those previously thought possible. The BDC’s unique see-through ballistic circles offer an incredible advantage 
for long range shooting—yet allow a normal sight picture for shorter-range shots where the crosshair itself is the aiming point.
Extremely bright sight picture: Allows for high-resolution images even when hunting in the least desirable conditions.
Versatile magnification range: Offers the flexibility needed for any type of hunting situation, from heavy timber to the open prairies.
Waterproof, fog proof, shockproof: Nitrogen filled and O-ring sealed. 
Multicoated optical system: Multicoated lenses boost light transmission up to 90%—unheard of in similarly priced scopes.
Generous, consistent eye relief: Keeps your brow safe—even with the heaviest recoiling cartridges, lightweight rifles, and severe shooting angles.
Precise hand-turn 1/4-MOA click adjustments: Positive-click reticle adjustments get you zeroed in quicker and 
maintain your setting even with heavy recoil.

147gn Total Metal Jacket 9mm luger (9x19mm) re-manufactured packed in 50 round boxes 
This is a great all around ammo. It's re-manufactured ammo. It's quiet through a silencer because it doesn't break the sound barrier (subsonic). title: For Sale:  Colt Official Police Post-war first year production - 1947 in 99%" condition
location: Spartanburg, Greenville, Woodruff, Greenville, South Carolina
postcontent: Colt Official Police Post-war first year production - 1947 in 99%" condition Original Walnut Grips Made from 1947 to 1969. Colt decided to rename the Army Special to more reflect the actual buyers of the gun, so the Army Special name was changed to the Official Police. The 1947 post-war version had a ramped and serrated front sight, a new shaped hammer with grooves, and the new cylinder retention system. That was just what the gun was, THE official police issue revolver for a great many police departments like the New York City Police, Boston Police, and Federal agencies like the FBI and Treasury Department. The Official Police would serve as a prime police issue gun into the 1960s, and was highly favored by private guard services, industrial plant guards, and civilian gun owners wanting a powerful and strong revolver.

title: For Sale:  ELCAN THERMAL SCOPE
postcontent:
The Elcan Spector infrared thermal scope is highly rugged military spec optic. These scopes were only available to federal law enforcement and military. It operates in the infrared spectrum which allows for use in the day or night regardless of ambient light conditions. The Specter IR does not emit visible or infrared radiation making it well suited for covert operation. It has 2X magnification with a focus field from 10 meters to infinity. It operates from 3 AA lithium batteries and weighs 3lbs. The scope is equipped with a video output connector that can be attached to a recording device or computer through a a standard AV cable. Mounted to your weapon on a MIL STD 1913 Picatinny rail the scope is sighted by adjustments to wind age and elevation through the mount. Simply record the settings for a specific weapon and move it to the weapon of your choice. Using the scope unmounted allows the user to be aware of the presence of game during hours of darkness while not violating any regulations. As a survalence device the Specter IR can be mounted and used to record activity or collect evidence that would otherwise be invisible. This is a high quality device with unlimited potential to the hunter, tactical shooter, or investigator. This scope was used by the Department of Energy at fixed facilities. It is without defects. The Specter IR is restricted from export.

title: For Sale:  Marlin XS7 .223 Rem with Nikon scope
postcontent:
This is a gun that I have really enjoyed shooting. I bought it last year in the beginning of November, they usually go for around 360. The rifle has had about 500 rounds through it, it shoots pretty good. To break it in and for plinking I’ve been shooting Wolf Gold, which groups pretty good for cheap ammo at about 1.5 inches. HPR ammo with 55 gr. VMAX bullets shoots at about 1 inch. 24 grains of IMR 4198 with a 55 gr Sierra varminter bullet was really good; I shot one group at about a half inch but honestly I’ve never been able to replicate that with those bullets. It really likes the 53 grain VMAX. 
So the gun shoots really well. I put a Nikon 3-9×40 scope with the BDC reticle, the scope came off of a Savage Trophy Hunter XP.  The scope with the rings is worth about 150.
I glass bedded the action and the fore end of the stock to stiffen it up. It made it a little heavier but it shoots better. The X7 or XS7 is is a good gun, they basically just combined all the popular parts from all the guns into this one (Rem 700 safety, Win 70 bases and bold release, Savage trigger and barrel nut).
I'm selling this gun because I don't really shoot it much but I still like it so I'm firm on the price.
208-339-zero1nine8.
Here are a couple review that were done about this gun:
http://www.americanrifleman.org/articles/2013/12/11/the-marlin-x7/
http://www.shootingtimes.com/long-guns/longgun_reviews_marlin_corners_the_market_102910/
http://www.gunblast.com/Marlin-XL7.htm
